sentence: Hive actors(This is Attack Group) have gained initial access to victim networks by using single factor logins via Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP)(This is Software Tool), virtual private networks (VPNs)(This is Software Tool), and other remote network connection protocols [T1133].

In some cases, Hive actors(This is Attack Group) have bypassed multifactor authentication (MFA) and gained access to FortiOS(This is Software Tool) servers by exploiting Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) CVE 2020 12812.
This vulnerability enables a malicious cyber actor to log in without a prompt for the user’s second authentication factor (FortiToken) when the actor changes the case of the username.

Hive actors(This is Attack Group) have also gained initial access to victim networks by distributing phishing emails(This is Software Tool) with malicious attachments(This is Software Tool) [T1566.001] and by exploiting the following vulnerabilities against Microsoft Exchange servers [T1190]: CVE 2021 31207 Microsoft Exchange Server Security Feature Bypass Vulnerability(This is Software Tool) CVE 2021 34473 Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability(This is Software Tool) CVE 2021 34523 Microsoft Exchange Server Privilege Escalation Vulnerability(This is Software Tool) After gaining access, Hive ransomware(This is Software Tool) attempts to evade detention by executing processes to: Identify processes related to backups, antivirus/anti spyware, and file copying and then terminating those processes to facilitate file encryption [T1562].
Stop the volume shadow copy services and remove all existing shadow copies via vssadmin(This is Software Tool) on command line(This is Software Tool) or via PowerShell [T1059] [T1490].
Delete Windows event logs, specifically the System, Security and Application logs [T1070].
Prior to encryption, Hive ransomware(This is Software Tool) removes virus definitions and disables all portions of Windows Defender and other common antivirus programs in the system registry [T1112].
Hive actors(This is Attack Group) exfiltrate data likely using a combination of Rclone(This is Software Tool) and the cloud storage service Mega.nz(This is Software Tool) [T1537].
During the encryption process, a file named File (previously File ) is created in the root directory (C:\ or Filepath ).
The ransom note, File is dropped into each affected directory and states the File file cannot be modified, renamed, or deleted, otherwise the encrypted files cannot be recovered [T1486].

The ransom note contains a “sales department” .onion link accessible through a TOR browser(This is Software Tool), enabling victim organizations to contact the actors(This is Attack Group) through a live chat panel to discuss payment for their files.

The ransom note also threatens victims that a public disclosure or leak site accessible on the TOR site, “Hive(This is Attack Group)Leaks”, contains data exfiltrated from victim organizations who do not pay the ransom demand (see figure 1 below).
Once the victim organization contacts Hive actors(This is Attack Group) on the live chat panel, Hive actors communicate the ransom amount and the payment deadline.

Hive actors(This is Attack Group) have been known to reinfect—with either Hive ransomware(This is Software Tool) or another ransomware variant(This is Software Tool)—the networks of victim organizations who have restored their network without making a ransom payment.
Monitor remote access/RDP logs, enforce account lockouts after a specified number of attempts to block brute force campaigns, log RDP login attempts, and disable unused remote access/RDP ports.
Ensure your backup data is not already infected., Monitor cyber threat reporting regarding the publication of compromised VPN login credentials and change passwords/settings if applicable.
Isolate the infected system.
Remove the infected system from all networks, and disable the computer’s wireless, Bluetooth, and any other potential networking capabilities.
Ensure all shared and networked drives are disconnected.
Power off and segregate (i.e., remove from the network) the infected computer(s).
Power off and segregate any other computers or devices that share a network with the infected computer(s) that have not been fully encrypted by ransomware(This is Software Tool).
Add password user “salts” to shared login credentials.
Implement multiple failed login attempt account lockouts.
Require administrator credentials to install software.
Review domain controllers, servers, workstations, and active directories for new and/or unrecognized accounts.

Network segmentation can help prevent the spread of ransomware(This is Software Tool) by controlling traffic flows between—and access to—various subnetworks and by restricting adversary lateral movement.
Identify, detect, and investigate abnormal activity and potential traversal of the indicated ransomware(This is Software Tool) with a networking monitoring tool(This is Software Tool).
To aid in detecting the ransomware(This is Software Tool), implement a tool that logs and reports all network traffic, including lateral movement activity on a network(This is Software Tool).
Disable command line(This is Software Tool) and scripting activities and permissions.
Privilege escalation and lateral movement often depend on software utilities running from the command line(This is Software Tool).
If threat actors(This is Attack Group) are not able to run these tools, they will have difficulty escalating privileges and/or moving laterally.
Restrict Server Message Block (SMB(This is Software Tool)) Protocol within the network to only access necessary servers and remove or disable outdated versions of SMB (i.e., SMB version 1).
Threat actors(This is Attack Group) use SMB(This is Software Tool) to propagate malware across organizations.
